"We could establish the same principle," he continues. "Equipment issued from royal stores remains Crown property. The soldier signs a receipt—or makes his mark—acknowledging custody. Sir Thomas nods. "The English do something similar with longbows. Crown property, issued for service, returned or accounted for. It works—mostly. The difficulty is enforcement when armies disperse after campaign."
